context: the patient is an 8-year-old child with history of recurrent otitis media.
procedure performed: bilateral myringotomy tubes and adenoidectomy.
the patient is an 8-year-old child with history of recurrent otitis media.
the patient has had previous tube placement.
tubes have since plugged and are no more functioning.
risks and benefits in terms of bleeding, anesthesia, and tympanic membrane perforation were discussed with the mother.
risks and benefits in terms of bleeding, anesthesia, and tympanic membrane perforation were discussed with the mother.
risks and benefits in terms of bleeding, anesthesia, and tympanic membrane perforation were discussed with the mother.
after removing the tube the patient was found to have microperforation through which serous fluid was draining.
after removing the tube the patient was found to have microperforation through which serous fluid was draining.

in the right ear again under microscopic visualization, the ear was cleaned, the tube was removed off tympanic membrane. there was no perforation seen; however, there was some granulation tissue on the surface of tympanic membrane.
under mirror visualization, the nasopharynx was examined. the patient was found to have minimal adenoidal tissue.
under mirror visualization, the nasopharynx was examined. the patient was found to have minimal adenoidal tissue.
more serous fluid was drained out of middle ear space. the tube was easily placed and floxin drops were placed in the ear.

using a small mcivor mouth gag mouth was held open. using a rubber catheter the soft palate was retracted. under mirror visualization, the nasopharynx was examined. the patient was found to have minimal adenoidal tissue. this was removed using a suction bovie.
